title: 103_hr3810
content: The Act may be cited as the "Rural Community Wastewater Treatment Affordability Act of 1994". Eligibility criteria are outlined in the Act. The "Rural Community Wastewater Treatment Affordability Act of 1994" outlines eligibility criteria for acquiring lands, easements, and rights-of-ways necessary for construction of treatment works. It also includes provisions for rural nonprofit water associations to provide wastewater treatment and water supply services to communities. SEC. 3. CAPITALIZATION GRANT AGREEMENTS. Amends the Federal Water Pollution Control Act to encourage the use of innovative and cost-effective technologies in the construction of treatment works financed with assistance provided from the fund. The Loan Program under the Federal Water Pollution Control Act is amended to provide loans to rural and disadvantaged communities at or below market interest rates, including interest free and negative-interest loans, with terms not exceeding 40 years or the useful life of the project. The Loan Program under the Federal Water Pollution Control Act is amended to provide loans to rural and disadvantaged communities at terms not to exceed 40 years or the useful life of the project being financed. The Loan Program under the Federal Water Pollution Control Act is amended to provide loans to rural and disadvantaged communities, with a limit of 15 percent of all loans for negative-interest loans. Planning grants to disadvantaged communities are also addressed in the amendment. The amendment includes making grants to rural and disadvantaged communities to cover up to 75 percent of planning and predevelopment costs for treatment works without requiring actual construction of the project. The amendment allows rural and disadvantaged communities to receive grants covering up to 75 percent of planning and predevelopment costs for treatment works, with a maximum grant amount of $75,000 per project. The amendment allows rural and disadvantaged communities to receive grants covering up to 75 percent of planning and predevelopment costs for treatment works, with a maximum grant amount of $75,000 per project. Additionally, the Federal grant awards to the water pollution control revolving fund shall not exceed 2 percent in a fiscal year, with a limit of $75,000 per project. The term 'rural and disadvantaged communities' refers to service areas of publicly owned treatment works in states, excluding areas with a population over 10,000 and a median household income exceeding 75% of the national median. The term 'negative-interest loan' is also defined. The term 'negative-interest loan' refers to a zero percent interest loan provided by a State to rural and disadvantaged communities, with a forgiveness of up to 20 percent of the principal over the loan term. SEC. 5 amends the Federal Water Pollution Control Act regarding administrative costs. SEC. 6 introduces a technical assistance grant program under the Act. The Administrator may grant funds to organizations for training and assistance in rural communities for treatment works. $15,000,000 per fiscal year is authorized for this program until 1998. A conforming amendment is made to Section 607 of the Act. The Administrator may grant $15,000,000 per fiscal year until 1998 for training and assistance in rural communities for treatment works.
